newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico peso ends firm on dollars entering bourse.
newsitem.headline: Mexico peso ends firm on dollars entering bourse.

text.p: Longer Mexican peso contracts reversed early weakness to close firmer on Wednesday as a strong inflow of foreign investors to the bourse fended off the adverse effect of plummeting primary rates, traders said.
"The peso is strong even though they brought rates down sharply," a dealer said. "Dollars flooding into the bourse would not let it weaken."
The benchmark 48-hour peso and its 24-hour stablemate ended 0.45 and 0.8 of a centavo firmer, respectively, at 7.7840/7.7890 and 7.7800/7.7830 per dollar.
Bellwether 28-day Cetes rates plunged 176 basis points to 19.69 percent at Tuesday night's central bank auction, which made peso contracts open weak.
Nonetheless, local share prices rallied to new record highs in early trade as foreign traders stepped in to buy. Dealers said the resulting supply of dollars bolstered the peso.
The leading share IPC index was up 1.43 percent at 3,803.80 points when the foreign exchange market closed.
Traders said local corporations selling dollars also helped bolster the peso.
Dealers predicted that 48-hour peso contracts could weaken Thursday due to swaps ahead of the long weekend in the United States. Markets will close on Monday for President's Day.
Same-day peso contracts closed earlier 0.25 of a centavo weaker at 7.7840/7.7890 per dollar.
